title: Hartman Personality Profile
text:
The Color Code Personality Profile also known as "The Color Code" or "The People Code" is a personality inventory devised by Taylor Hartman. A 45-question <a href="personality%20test">personality test</a> is used to assess one's color.
Classifying the motive types.
The Hartman Personality Profile is based on the notion that all people possess one of four driving "core motives". "The Color Code" is based on four types of <a href="personality">personality</a>, identified by color: <a href="Red">Red</a>, (<a href="motivation">motivated</a> by <a href="power%20%28social%20and%20political%29">power</a>); <a href="Blue">Blue</a>, (motivated by <a href="intimacy">intimacy</a>); <a href="White">White</a>, (motivated by <a href="peace">peace</a>); and <a href="Yellow">Yellow</a>, (motivated by <a href="fun">fun</a>). Although <a href="demographics">demographic groups</a> vary, the general breakdown suggests that Reds comprise 25% of the <a href="population">population</a>; Blues 35%; Whites 20%; and Yellows 20%.
Reds.
Reds are power wielders. They use <a href="logic">logic</a>, <a href="Insight">vision</a> and <a href="Self-determination">determination</a>. From a Red perspective, <a href="emotion">emotion</a> has nothing to do with completing tasks.
Strengths.
Reds are: action-oriented, <a href="assertive">assertive</a>, <a href="confident">confident</a>, <a href="decision%20making">decisive</a>, determined, <a href="discipline">discipline</a>d, <a href="wikt%3Aindependent">independent</a>, <a href="leader">leader</a>s, logical, <a href="Pragmatism">pragmatic</a>, <a href="proactive">proactive</a>, <a href="productive">productive</a>, <a href="Social%20responsibility">responsible</a>, and task-dominant.
Limitations.
Reds often need to be right. They may come across as harsh and <a href="criticism">critical</a>, even when they don't mean to. They tend to give priority to work over <a href="personal%20relationship">personal relationship</a>s. Reds may be poor <a href="listening">listeners</a>. They can also exhibit <a href="control%20freak">controlling</a> and domineering <a href="Trait%20theory">traits</a>.
Blues.
Life is a sequence of <a href="promise">commitments</a> for blues. They thrive on <a href="Interpersonal%20relationship">relationships</a> and willingly sacrifice personal gain. Blues are highly <a href="demand">demand</a>ing <a href="perfectionism%20%28psychology%29">perfectionists</a>. They can be distrusting and <a href="worry">worry</a>-prone. They are complex and <a href="intuition%20%28psychology%29">intuitive</a> and can be very <a href="opinion">opinion</a>ated. Blues can also be emotional and <a href="mood%20%28psychology%29">moody</a>. Blues can be self-righteous and <a href="Emotional%20security">insecure</a> and can also be very <a href="self-discipline">self-discipline</a>d and <a href="sincere">sincere</a>.
Strengths.
Blues are steady, ordered and <a href="enduring">enduring</a>. Blues <a href="love">love</a> with <a href="passion%20%28emotion%29">passion</a>. They bring <a href="culture">culture</a> and dependency to <a href="society">society</a> and <a href="home">home</a>. They are highly committed and <a href="loyalty">loyal</a>. They are comfortable in <a href="creativity">creative</a> environments. They strive to be the best they can be.
Limitations.
Blues are the most controlling of the four colors. They can be <a href="Emotional%20security">insecure</a> and <a href="judgmental">judgmental</a>. Lacking <a href="trust%20%28social%20sciences%29">trust</a>, they find themselves <a href="resentful">resentful</a> or <a href="forgive">unforgiving</a>. They often <a href="failure">fail</a> at seeing the positive side of life. They want to be loved and <a href="accepted">accepted</a>, constantly seeking understanding from others while often refusing to <a href="understand">understand</a> and accept themselves.
Whites.
Motivated by peace, Whites will do anything to avoid <a href="confrontation">confrontation</a>. Their only demands from life are the things that make them feel <a href="comfortable">comfortable</a>. That feeling fosters their <a href="need">need</a> to feel good inside.
Strengths.
Whites are kind, considerate, <a href="patient">patient</a>, and accepting. They are devoid of <a href="Id%2C%20ego%20and%20super-ego%23Ego">ego</a>. They are good at constructing <a href="thoughts">thoughts</a> that did not exist before, just from careful listening and taking time to think things through.
Limitations.
Whites don't commonly share what they are feeling, understanding or seeing. They won't <a href="emotional%20expression">express</a> conflict. Whites may be unwilling to set <a href="goal">goal</a>s. They dislike working at someone else's pace. They can be somewhat <a href="self-deprecation">self-deprecating</a>.
Yellows.
Yellows are motivated by fun. They seek to have a great time.
Strengths.
Yellows are <a href="enthusiasm">enthusiastic</a>, very <a href="persuasion">persuasive</a>, and spontaneous in nature. They are always looking for something new to do.
Limitations.
They develop <a href="friendships">friendships</a> with ease but can be very <a href="self-centered">self-centered</a>, keeping them from forming meaningful relationships. Often they have lots of friends, but only on a <a href="superficiality">superficial</a> level. Yellows may have difficulty getting down to business.
Criticism.
The Hartman Institute and its many subsidiaries offer "coaches" to businesses seeking to improve interpersonal relations, for career counseling, or to collect data for use in hiring practices. The test informally passes most psychometric measures of reliability and face validity, but this may be attributed to the open predictability of the test. The criteria are likely self-fulfilling to an extent. Although internal and small sample corporate-sponsored data have been reported, no peer-reviewed studies of the psychometric value of the test exist.
